name: Haley Moss
description: FL Attorney. #ActuallyAutistic. Author. Advocate. Educator. Passionate about neurodiversity, inclusion, mental health, and also lawyers. Pok√©mon stan. She/her
tweet: The writing process looks like this: "Why are we having late Dx's in marginalized communities and we're used to talking about BIPOC or cis women" becomes "How do I make sure any reader, especially autistic readers, feel accurately represented in an article about our stories?"

name: Haley Moss
description: FL Attorney. #ActuallyAutistic. Author. Advocate. Educator. Passionate about neurodiversity, inclusion, mental health, and also lawyers. Pok√©mon stan. She/her
tweet: It's not easy conveying nuance in tweets, and if you've ever written about nuanced, difficult subjects for the general public, that's also difficult. Pieces and the needs we have for our work also morphs over time.

tweet: @autienelle My family didn‚Äôt subject me to ABA. We did speech, OT, floortime. I was a happy kid. My parents are super supportive and advocated alongside me. Knowing I was autistic during childhood was incredibly meaningful for me and shaped my entire adolescence.

name: Haley Moss
description: FL Attorney. #ActuallyAutistic. Author. Advocate. Educator. Passionate about neurodiversity, inclusion, mental health, and also lawyers. Pok√©mon stan. She/her
tweet: @AutismAudacity I think savior complexes are in the same vein, but a subset of benevolent ableism since folks who perpetuate it are usually good people who want to be allies and help ‚Äî but end up stepping on our autonomy and self-advocacy in the process by thinking they know what‚Äôs best for us.

name: Haley Moss
description: FL Attorney. #ActuallyAutistic. Author. Advocate. Educator. Passionate about neurodiversity, inclusion, mental health, and also lawyers. Pok√©mon stan. She/her
tweet:
Something that makes benevolent ableism hard is it very often comes from good people. It comes from friends & loved ones.

How can you be a better ally?

Practice inclusion in everyday situations! Take the opportunity to hear us out & listen. Let us make our own decisions.

name: Haley Moss
description: FL Attorney. #ActuallyAutistic. Author. Advocate. Educator. Passionate about neurodiversity, inclusion, mental health, and also lawyers. Pok√©mon stan. She/her

name: Haley Moss
description: FL Attorney. #ActuallyAutistic. Author. Advocate. Educator. Passionate about neurodiversity, inclusion, mental health, and also lawyers. Pok√©mon stan. She/her
tweet: @AutismAudacity A very nice person on Instagram asked tonight what the difference was between genuine help & benevolent ableism and it got me thinking

name: Haley Moss
description: FL Attorney. #ActuallyAutistic. Author. Advocate. Educator. Passionate about neurodiversity, inclusion, mental health, and also lawyers. Pok√©mon stan. She/her
tweet:
Why is this harmful?

Benevolent ableism is good faith, but speaks over or silences autistic & disabled people, where neurotypical, nondisabled people decide what‚Äôs best for us without our consent.

It robs us of self-advocacy & independence. It can be a subtle form of exclusion.

name: Haley Moss
description: FL Attorney. #ActuallyAutistic. Author. Advocate. Educator. Passionate about neurodiversity, inclusion, mental health, and also lawyers. Pok√©mon stan. She/her
tweet:
What‚Äôs the difference between genuine help & benevolent ableism?

Genuine help is consensual. Autistic or disabled people will accept an offer of help or ask for help.

Benevolent ableism happens when well-intentioned people attempt to help when it‚Äôs neither asked for nor wanted.

name: Haley Moss
description: FL Attorney. #ActuallyAutistic. Author. Advocate. Educator. Passionate about neurodiversity, inclusion, mental health, and also lawyers. Pok√©mon stan. She/her
tweet: Benevolent ableism seemingly happens with the best of intentions.

name: Haley Moss
description: FL Attorney. #ActuallyAutistic. Author. Advocate. Educator. Passionate about neurodiversity, inclusion, mental health, and also lawyers. Pok√©mon stan. She/her
tweet:
Let‚Äôs talk about benevolent ableism, since we‚Äôre gonna see a lot of it in #AutismAcceptanceMonth :

Benevolent ableism is the discrimination & negative treatment and stereotypes facing people with disabilities, but disguised as kind & caring.

name: Haley Moss
description: FL Attorney. #ActuallyAutistic. Author. Advocate. Educator. Passionate about neurodiversity, inclusion, mental health, and also lawyers. Pok√©mon stan. She/her
tweet:
‚ÄúVaccines cause autism.‚Äù

We‚Äôve been dealing with this stigma for a long time. Also really not cool when #VaccinesSaveLives & we‚Äôre living through a pandemic trying to protect people! Anti-vaxx sentiment makes this April extra hard for autistic people, so extend grace to us.

name: Haley Moss
description: FL Attorney. #ActuallyAutistic. Author. Advocate. Educator. Passionate about neurodiversity, inclusion, mental health, and also lawyers. Pok√©mon stan. She/her
tweet:
‚ÄúYou are living with autism.‚Äù

If this was true, autism is a terrible roommate! Autism does not do its laundry or unload the dishwasher.

name: Haley Moss
description: FL Attorney. #ActuallyAutistic. Author. Advocate. Educator. Passionate about neurodiversity, inclusion, mental health, and also lawyers. Pok√©mon stan. She/her
tweet:
‚ÄúAutism is a disability. You shouldn‚Äôt be proud of that.‚Äù

The #ActuallyAutistic community, as well as other disabled and neurodivergent communities, would like a word with you about identity & pride. Autistic culture is real and vibrant, and I recommend you learn about that. ü§ó

name: Haley Moss
description: FL Attorney. #ActuallyAutistic. Author. Advocate. Educator. Passionate about neurodiversity, inclusion, mental health, and also lawyers. Pok√©mon stan. She/her
tweet:
‚ÄúYou do not speak for all autistic people.‚Äù

You‚Äôre right. I can only speak for myself and my own experiences. Seek out and amplify other autistic voices. I promise, we‚Äôre all better for that ‚Äî myself included.

name: Haley Moss
description: FL Attorney. #ActuallyAutistic. Author. Advocate. Educator. Passionate about neurodiversity, inclusion, mental health, and also lawyers. Pok√©mon stan. She/her
tweet:
‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not autistic! You‚Äôre a person with autism.‚Äù

I say I‚Äôm autistic since it‚Äôs a huge part of who I am. Some identify as having autism. Ask the autistic people in your life how they describe themselves. Respect and honor those choices, even if they‚Äôre different than yours.

name: Haley Moss
description: FL Attorney. #ActuallyAutistic. Author. Advocate. Educator. Passionate about neurodiversity, inclusion, mental health, and also lawyers. Pok√©mon stan. She/her
tweet:
‚ÄúAren‚Äôt you like, a math/computer genius?‚Äù

There‚Äôs a stereotype that all autistic people are excellent programmers & math whizzes. Some of us are! But for those who are not, it‚Äôs harmful: we might feel pressured to pursue that or ignore our strengths.

I went to law school, so.

name: Haley Moss
description: FL Attorney. #ActuallyAutistic. Author. Advocate. Educator. Passionate about neurodiversity, inclusion, mental health, and also lawyers. Pok√©mon stan. She/her
tweet:
‚ÄúI thought only boys / white people / people from westernized countries have autism!‚Äù

Friends, there are inequities that exist amongst race, gender, and culture when identifying autism. How can we ensure everyone has access to a diagnosis & services?

name: Haley Moss
description: FL Attorney. #ActuallyAutistic. Author. Advocate. Educator. Passionate about neurodiversity, inclusion, mental health, and also lawyers. Pok√©mon stan. She/her
tweet:
‚ÄúYour autism isn‚Äôt like my cousin‚Äôs brother‚Äôs autism.‚Äù

You‚Äôre right! I am not a boy, I am an adult woman. Also, every autistic person has unique strengths and challenges. As the saying goes, ‚Äúif you‚Äôve met one autistic person, you‚Äôve met one autistic person.‚Äù

name: Haley Moss
description: FL Attorney. #ActuallyAutistic. Author. Advocate. Educator. Passionate about neurodiversity, inclusion, mental health, and also lawyers. Pok√©mon stan. She/her
tweet:
‚ÄúI never would‚Äôve known if you didn‚Äôt tell me‚Äù

I have a lot of coping strategies including masking, and autistic people often do extra work to be accepted or make neurotypicals feel more comfortable. 

Instead, consider how you can be more inclusive/be glad someone disclosed.

name: Haley Moss
description: FL Attorney. #ActuallyAutistic. Author. Advocate. Educator. Passionate about neurodiversity, inclusion, mental health, and also lawyers. Pok√©mon stan. She/her
tweet:
Things to avoid saying during #AutismAcceptanceMonth, a thread:

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre all on the spectrum.‚Äù

I know you‚Äôre trying hard to relate, but no, we‚Äôre not. Autistic people each have unique experiences, challenges, and skills.

But at events generally, offer water/soda/nonalcoholic beverages as alternatives, no questions asked.

name: Haley Moss
description: FL Attorney. #ActuallyAutistic. Author. Advocate. Educator. Passionate about neurodiversity, inclusion, mental health, and also lawyers. Pok√©mon stan. She/her
tweet:
Virtual wine & beer tastings are kind of like the new virtual happy hours. But I can't help to think how uncomfortable they must be for folks who don't drink.

No one owes you an explanation why they will or won't drink. We need to do better at making sure everyone feels welcome.

name: Haley Moss
description: FL Attorney. #ActuallyAutistic. Author. Advocate. Educator. Passionate about neurodiversity, inclusion, mental health, and also lawyers. Pok√©mon stan. She/her
tweet:
Inclusion tip: don't have social events (even virtual ones) revolve around alcohol.

People don't drink for a variety of reasons (moral, personal, disability, mental health, etc.). They shouldn't always feel pressured to disclose why or feel they have to opt out of socializing!

name: Haley Moss

tweet:
Anyway, I'd love to see this discussion of professional titling continue especially from folks who are multiply marginalized. 

tl;dr I don't use "JD" or "Esq." titles lightly or to be obnoxious or elitist whatsoever. It's to demonstrate competence where it is not presumed.

name: Haley Moss
description: FL Attorney. #ActuallyAutistic. Author. Advocate. Educator. Passionate about neurodiversity, inclusion, mental health, and also lawyers. Pok√©mon stan. She/her
tweet: This is a messy, complicated question dependent on a person's background. Women and nonbinary folks, BIPOC, LGBTQ+ folks, and disabled people know we have to overcome biases and barriers. Sometimes explicitly sharing our titles gives the presumption of competence.

name: Haley Moss
description: FL Attorney. #ActuallyAutistic. Author. Advocate. Educator. Passionate about neurodiversity, inclusion, mental health, and also lawyers. Pok√©mon stan. She/her
tweet: I know as an #ActuallyAutistic lawyer I hold extra privilege. But sometimes in disability spaces I have to use that Esquire title to say "Hi I know about legal disability stuff BEYOND my personal experience." The personal & professional inform each other" and can't be separated.

name: Haley Moss
description: FL Attorney. #ActuallyAutistic. Author. Advocate. Educator. Passionate about neurodiversity, inclusion, mental health, and also lawyers. Pok√©mon stan. She/her
tweet:
This is a complicated question for me.

Do I? Yes.

Do I want to? No.

But sometimes when you are disabled or neurodivergent (or somehow marginalized), that reinforcement is what forces certain individuals to give you the respect you deserve regardless of title or education. https://t.co/H7dVMUE01Y

name: Haley Moss

name: Haley Moss

tweet: You should want to be my friend because I am cool and interesting and fun. Maybe you'll learn something and grow, maybe not. I don't want you to solely be my friend because it makes you look like a Good Person or because you want to write about on a college application.

name: Haley Moss
description: FL Attorney. #ActuallyAutistic. Author. Advocate. Educator. Passionate about neurodiversity, inclusion, mental health, and also lawyers. Pok√©mon stan. She/her

name: Haley Moss

tweet: There are plenty of programs that rock & do work promoting inclusion + friendships between neurotypicals and people with I/DD. NT students might sign up for community service hours or some other benefit. How do we make sure there are real friendships vs. obligatory friendships?

name: Haley Moss

tweet:

Individual advocacy can be collaborative & should be in the best interest of the disabled person.

name: Haley Moss
description: FL Attorney. #ActuallyAutistic. Author. Advocate. Educator. Passionate about neurodiversity, inclusion, mental health, and also lawyers. Pok√©mon stan. She/her
tweet:

tweet: There were times I wanted to drop because the schedule was exhausting or the process felt demanding. If I didn't have trust or comfort at any point in the process, I'd have pulled the plug then. Films only have the potential to be as good as a subject's level of access granted.

name: Haley Moss

tweet: @GregAndree71 Honestly, picking subjects depends on who is willing to give time, how willing they are to be in these situations, who is willing to share what, what the subject's goals are. name: Haley Moss
description: FL Attorney. #ActuallyAutistic. Author. Advocate. Educator. Passionate about neurodiversity, inclusion, mental health, and also lawyers. Pok√©mon stan. She/her
tweet:
Keep in mind I have little experience with staged situations. I was not part of a documentary that had staged and unnatural situations like the dates in #LoveOnTheSpectrum. 

Imagine how weird it is having a film crew watch you meet someone for a first date they arranged for you.

name: Haley Moss
description: FL Attorney. #ActuallyAutistic. Author. Advocate. Educator. Passionate about neurodiversity, inclusion, mental health, and also lawyers. Pok√©mon stan. She/her
tweet:
The filmmakers want you rooting for everyone.

The restaurant spaces were likely rented out hence the lack of people and high staging (flowers, lighting, waiters, the "time to go" moments). Subjects were likely pulled for interviews mid-date.

name: Haley Moss

tweet: @torriangray I haven't watched a documentary since seeing the 30 minute one I was the subject of back in February (I have only seen it once), so this is an entirely new perspective to watch from.

name: Haley Moss
description: FL Attorney. #ActuallyAutistic. Author. Advocate. Educator. Passionate about neurodiversity, inclusion, mental health, and also lawyers. Pok√©mon stan. She/her
tweet: @torriangray When you hear narration from the subjects not shown alongside the clips, those things were likely said in completely different contexts & spliced that way. It happened a lot with me - we'd be having some random convo and then I'd say something insightful & have to repeat it

name: Haley Moss
description: FL Attorney. #ActuallyAutistic. Author. Advocate. Educator. Passionate about neurodiversity, inclusion, mental health, and also lawyers. Pok√©mon stan. She/her
tweet: Documentary, docu-series, or reality TV filming are inherently unnatural experiences, even with mutual trust between filmmaker & subject. #LoveOnTheSpectrum is no exception. I applaud the vulnerability & openness of the #ActuallyAutistic folks & their families who participated.

name: Haley Moss
description: FL Attorney. #ActuallyAutistic. Author. Advocate. Educator. Passionate about neurodiversity, inclusion, mental health, and also lawyers. Pok√©mon stan. She/her
tweet: So I want to be patient and empathetic towards #LoveOnTheSpectrum subjects. When I was a doc subject, I was not shown in unnatural situations or things that would never happen outside of my life. The closest thing to it was an introspective beach visit that didn't make the cut.

name: Haley Moss
description: FL Attorney. #ActuallyAutistic. Author. Advocate. Educator. Passionate about neurodiversity, inclusion, mental health, and also lawyers. Pok√©mon stan. She/her
tweet: In filming, I learned that a "typical" task - like cooking, entering through a door, getting ready for work - takes about 3x longer than it would without a camera present because of getting a shot right, adding narration, or other interruptions.

name: Haley Moss
description: FL Attorney. #ActuallyAutistic. Author. Advocate. Educator. Passionate about neurodiversity, inclusion, mental health, and also lawyers. Pok√©mon stan. She/her

name: Haley Moss
description: FL Attorney. #ActuallyAutistic. Author. Advocate. Educator. Passionate about neurodiversity, inclusion, mental health, and also lawyers. Pok√©mon stan. She/her
tweet:
We have a lot of work to do still! 

Disabled folks still face barriers in education and employment.

Disability rights intersects with race, class, sex and gender, religion, and all forms of marginalization and must be treated as such too.

name: Haley Moss

tweet:

It's awesome we have the ADA, but there is still a lot of work to be done to dismantle and unlearn ableism.

tweet: @GwendolynKansen It‚Äôs true. For some reason modern history just seems to pass the torch on eugenics to the Nazis, and occasionally mentions Buck v Bell. but American eugenics were in full swing before the Holocaust and WW2. I think it‚Äôs important people know Nazis got those ideas from us.

name: Haley Moss
description: FL Attorney. #ActuallyAutistic. Author. Advocate. Educator. Passionate about neurodiversity, inclusion, mental health, and also lawyers. Pok√©mon stan. She/her
tweet:
North Carolina had eugenics boards until 1974. The state also had a law surrounding forced sterilization of disabled folks that my former boss critiqued as a young lawyer in 1996 (his critique now appears in a bioethics law book): 

https://t.co/VzUtvYRfVw

name: Haley Moss
description: FL Attorney. #ActuallyAutistic. Author. Advocate. Educator. Passionate about neurodiversity, inclusion, mental health, and also lawyers. Pok√©mon stan. She/her
tweet:
American eugenics occurred after World War II and the Nazi atrocities. American eugenics forcibly sterilized

Virginia had eugenics boards and forced sterilization until 1979.

https://t.co/WyQOii47J0

name: Haley Moss
description: FL Attorney. #ActuallyAutistic. Author. Advocate. Educator. Passionate about neurodiversity, inclusion, mental health, and also lawyers. Pok√©mon stan. She/her
tweet:
American eugenics emboldened the Nazis. Aktion-T4 was how Nazis exterminated and killed disabled people. Mengele did terrible things. We gave ideas. Buck v Bell inspired the Nazis.

At the Nuremberg trials, lawyers for Nazi scientists cited the opinion in defense of their actions

name: Haley Moss
description: FL Attorney. #ActuallyAutistic. Author. Advocate. Educator. Passionate about neurodiversity, inclusion, mental health, and also lawyers. Pok√©mon stan. She/her
tweet:

https://t.co/mOmtINaG7E

name: Haley Moss
description: FL Attorney. #ActuallyAutistic. Author. Advocate. Educator. Passionate about neurodiversity, inclusion, mental health, and also lawyers. Pok√©mon stan. She/her
tweet: Skinner v Oklahoma (1942) reached SCOTUS and overturned Oklahoma‚Äôs Habitual Sterilization Act of 1935. It didn‚Äôt particularly address disabled people but its reasoning was used to undermine the Buck v Bell decision.

name: Haley Moss
description: FL Attorney. #ActuallyAutistic. Author. Advocate. Educator. Passionate about neurodiversity, inclusion, mental health, and also lawyers. Pok√©mon stan. She/her
tweet:
So since everyone‚Äôs talking about eugenics, here‚Äôs some fun legal history for everyone!

Buck v Bell (1927), where Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes wrote ‚Äúthree generations of imbeciles are enough‚Äù - has never explicitly been overturned in the Supreme Court.

tweet:
Some very important questions to ask when writing stories about marginalized folks, especially disabled people:

1) Who is writing the story?
2) Who is the story about?
3) Who is missing from the story?
4) Who is the story written for?

name: Haley Moss
description: FL Attorney. #ActuallyAutistic. Author. Advocate. Educator. Passionate about neurodiversity, inclusion, mental health, and also lawyers. Pok√©mon stan. She/her
tweet:
@Magnus919 @JHMarble @EricMGarcia @scottkarp @Owen4Aidan @CarrieHall1001 @slooterman @aspergersgirls @UltranautsInc @autselfadvocacy @awnnetwork_ @aneeman @JustStimming @s_davanport I don't think theres such thing as true neutral. There is always a blatant or implied angle somewhere. 

In law, we're all naturally biased. We have to be zealous advocates. Judges have to apply the facts and pick a side that way. Mediators can't side with one party over another.
